noun.description: The quality of dealing with ideas rather than events.
examples: topics will vary in degrees of abstraction

noun.description: Freedom from representational qualities in art.
examples: geometric abstraction has been a mainstay in her work

noun.description: The process of considering something independently of its associations, attributes, or concrete accompaniments.
examples: duty is no longer determined in abstraction from the consequences

noun.description: The process of removing something, especially water from a river or other source.
examples: the abstraction of water from springs and wells

origin: Late Middle English: from Latin abstractio(n-), from the verb abstrahere draw away (see abstract).
